comments.text: Why people care and mad about fake frame? It gives you frames, so what if it's fake? Can you do better?
comments.author: @mashio0989

comments.text: Not only that but do these fake frames affect your real movement and day to day experience you see from your real eyes? Lmao people make it out to be so terrible when it only affects video games.... that are digital... on a screen... I can keep going. Lol I'm enjoying the hell out of my 5070 ti "fake" frames or not.
comments.author: @MerKilla

comments.text: These "fake frames" do not lessen the input lag which you want to get lower with higher FPS, a game with 200ms latency is absolutely unplayable even at 1000fps whereas a game with 15fps can be playable if the input lag is very low and the framerate is stable, it's all about the balance and those Fake Frames eat into your GPU's raster performance, meaning to get the extra fake frames you would give up actual good ones, and on top of that the overall PC latency increases. That's why it's bad. You don't want high FPS only for the image to be "smooth", you want the latency to be lower too, so the game feels more responsive.
comments.author: @Fr33mx

comments.text: @ it does not give up good frames to generate frames... the AI attempts to generate extra "fake" frames after the good ones by predicting the in game screen movement which is why ghosting and input latency happens. But all it takes is updates to improve the ai features for the gpus to make things more stable and run smoother. Nobody even really talks about fake frames anymore.
comments.author: @MerKilla

comments.text:
@MerKilla  it takes up processing power to produce and it also implements additional latency for the next frame to buffer for the system to keep working.
What I was referring to was about using some of your raster performance for the MFG, it makes you have fewer "native" frames.

comments.text:
You must be really young, if you feel that way about computers. This is the kind of improvement that people are used to:

1990: 1 million transistors operating at a speed of 33 megahertz
2000: 42 million transistors operating at a speed of 1000 megahertz (1 gigahertz)
2010: 1700 million (or 1.7 billion) transistors operating at a speed of 3300 megahertz (3.3 gigahertz)
2020: 27,000 million (or 27 billion) transistors operating at a speed of 5000 megahertz (5.0 gigahertz)

Compared to that, the past few generations have been downright anemic.
